Nonetheless, this is a highly difficult time for all aspiring barristers, and I want to be sure I am not the cause of anyone's distress. Unconditional support to everyone 🤍 this round can be positive or negative, but what it can't be, is a reflection of your self-worth 😠💗

Note: some tweets have been deleted before unlocking my account. This is to avoid anyone any negative feelings as I had opened up a bit about my personal progress this round, to illustrate why, as a disabled applicant, I am very careful about where I apply to.

If not an answer, then it's + regrettable

@AFCJupes @jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan I would hope so! Imho the only worse option (in the sense of: enabling this to unnecessarily spread) than a completely neutral statement, would be no statement at all. I drew an inference from the timing when someone sent it to me, I don't think it's unrelated.
RT @PaulinePaccard: 🇸🇾 Des images extrêmement fortes : à #Idleb hier des milliers de syriens anti Bachar ont voulu marquer le 11ème (oui 11…

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan We can agree to disagree, I personally believe that when faced with difficult choices, the only wrong one is refusing to choose at all. Transparency is not restating what you legally must do as a proof of good faith, it is making statements about the facts and your state of mind.

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan It is not. I would take their word for it, if they in fact gave their word. Them saying no decision has been made is far more persuasive than saying they will follow a process they are required to follow anyway. Stopping there seems like an easy escape.

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan It is plausible to think "yes, you are required to do so by your regulatory body, we want to know that a decision has not been taken". If I am legally required to interview 10 people, knowing I'm going to choose my bestie, I wouldn't be lying saying I am interviewing 10 people.

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan Transparency would require them to say it is both foolish and false that an applicant who is a relative has already been chosen. Because they are required by the BSB to sift through anonymised apps and hold interviews. They need to address the actual decision-making.

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan That's a misconception that people aren't capable of nuance. As I said, I believe that the process is fair by default. I'd like to see these accusations addressed head on so I don't start doubting why they refuse to confirm this rumour is false.

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan Scenario 2: they deny it. Some believe it, others don't. When the offer is made, if to the son, then most will surely question the denial's veracity. If to another applicant, they will think the denial was sincere they knew they had nothing to hide "eh, another TSR shitty moment"

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan Scenario 1: they don't deny it. People start saying it's rigged now. They'll say it's rigged even if the son has much earned his offer. If someone else gets it, they'll think it was because of bad publicity that the son didn't get it, because these people are set on these beliefs

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan If it won't make a difference to those who believe the rumour, but would make a difference to neutral people like me who only wish to hear "no, we haven't done this", then why not denying it ? Because a neutral statement convinces no one, a denial has at least some chances to

@K_L_Horgan @jameswmullen This neutral statement will definitely leave all applicants doubting the process. Even if they successfully get interviewed, they'll wonder whether the outcome has already been decided. That's trust being harmed.

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan I disagree, people are willing to believe the process is fair, but part of that is needing it being transparent. If issues (conflict of interests, nepotism or discrimination etc) are raised, then the reply should be as transparent as possible. If not, that's when trust is harmed

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan That would have looked suspicious in any circumstances, it would be for Chambers to assure that a fair process had been followed. Now if that happens in this cycle precisely, it'd be an amazing coincidence, and again, transparency is key in navigating these matters.

@jameswmullen @K_L_Horgan It would make a difference because whoever is recruited will be announced publicly prior to starting their pupillage. Denying it is the reassurance that the person who will be announced at that point then, whoever it is, will not be related to Members.

@K_L_Horgan I think they are only recruiting one pupil.. They are required to hold this process by the BSB in any event, so it is not evidence of either the veracity or falsity of that rumour. It really is a shame for their applicants who are already going through a difficult time 😔

@K_L_Horgan And as much as I am sure this is just yet another attempt to spread negative feelings on this forum, and the accusation is false, I don't see why the statement would not make sure to reassure all applicants of that. Maybe they think it does, but it doesn't

@K_L_Horgan Yes that's what I think is a shame. I really don't believe anything posted on that toxic forum which I avoid like the plague (no offense, most people there are perfectly fine, but some make it their mission to bring others down), but it's still a tough read for applicants

Hearing such a rumour must be absolutely heartbreaking to the applicants who spent hours on this form, putting in all the efforts, as well as lots of sweat, blood and tears. It should be paramount to reassure these hardworking applicants that their work will be properly valued.

But said Chambers has released a statement which does not straightforwardly address this rumour, let alone deny it. Why? I'm sure this is untrue, but it is still a serious accusation that should be met with a clear response, otherwise rumours will continue to spread.

So they are rumours that one Chambers (to which I haven't applied, not my area) has offered pupillage this very round, before even interviewing candidates, based on a personal relationship. Personally, I'm very skeptical of unsupported claims made anonymously on an infamous forum

Being part of the "less than 10% of barristers share this protected characteristic" team is wearisome. Many disabled Bar/Law students follow me, many struggle with their mental health. I want to tell you some have their arms wide open for us. It'll he harder, not impossible 🤍

As much as this has proved controversial recently, please know that you do need to put yourself out there and play the numbers game, but you'll save your time/energy/sanity by skipping the sets where you know, with certainty, that you will not be welcomed or valued.

@Steven_N_Emmott I just hope that people, especially those coming from under-representated backgrounds, ensure their wellbeing is never an afterthought in pursuing their dream career. But yes, absolutely, what that will mean in practice comes down to individual situations & individual priorities!

That's only my personal view. I can't say cancer as a teen/in my early 20s was fun, but I've learned to aim high and give my all to meet my goals, whilst being prepared to adjust my path in order to prioritise my wellbeing. Useful knowledge to navigate this complex process 😊

2) Your wellbeing and values come 1st. If you ever find yourself having been offered a place which you know will not be good for you, and will actually be detrimental to your wellbeing (some sets still bully candidates in ints...), please remember your career isn't everything

If you don't exp prejudice, then this is merely common sense to you. You won't have to undertake such a heavy and thorough work investigating whether your wellbeing will be jeopardised at every set you want to apply to. So this^ may well seem outlandish to you, but not to us.

If you are used to exp prejudice daily, this is of the utmost importance, you know it. Do your research religiously. As much as you can, try to avoid finding yourself having to spend 12 months in an unwelcoming (at best) environment. It's unfair, but you need to protect yourself.

This will carry varying weight depending on who you are. I've heard too many horror stories from black friends, who are now successful pupils/tenants, having awful exps with some sets. Same goes for my fellow disabled pupils/tenants.

^ obviously, if you receive an offer, you would be foolish to refuse it without good reasons. My points were mainly:

1) do not blindly apply everywhere, do your research & make sure you will fit in before applying to a set. Some places aren't meant for you, avoid applying there.

@ChrisMoran_101 Overall, I find the toll that the process takes on applicants' wellbeing and mental health so great, that we should all, and always, remember that our values & wellbeing are paramount and come first, then try to go from there.

@ChrisMoran_101 Amazing, it does only take one ! I too believe one should submit many apps, save when they know for sure they wouldn't belong and thrive at a particular set. Research is key. Sometimes you find out in int. you'd misjudged a set, then it's not too late to put yourself first!

@Steven_N_Emmott If it's either that or nothing, sometimes the best option may very well be nothing. Not having pupillage won't mean you weren't good enough/tried hard enough. It will mean you did your best in an impossible situation, but refused to compromise on your wellbeing. That's courage.

@Steven_N_Emmott By knowing that, you are able to assess when you should not settle for an opportunity which you can feel is not right for you, for many potential reasons (ie, some applicants exp downright bullying during int., if they receive an offer afterwards, should they accept it?)

@Steven_N_Emmott As many barristers tweeted, if they had to apply now, they wouldn't get pupillage, the standard has become unattainable. You don't lack courage when making every effort, but knowing that excellence may very well not cut it. And failure won't be a testament to your personality.

@Steven_N_Emmott Staying realistic and knowing your self-worth doesn't rely on your career has nothing to do with being pusillanimous. In a market where demand surpasses supply to such a large extent, it is not a lack of resolution to acknowledge that 'merit' has lost its meaning.

Be prepared to adjust to any hardship or change of course. 10 years ago I could have never imagined I would be where/who I am today. You don't know what's waiting for you in the future. You can only do your best right now, and trust that you will end up at the right place for you

Life is unpredictable. Aim high. Make every effort and always go the extra mile in everything that you do. Don't ever compromise your values or your wellbeing in that process. If it happens, then it has to happen the right way. Meanwhile, you shouldn't feel terrible all the time.

It's great to be ambitious, to have strong determination, and to work hard towards your goals. That really matters to me too. But you don't have to attach your self-worth to your professional success, or to knowingly apply to Chambers whose values are opposite to yours.

I hope to soon see joint statements addressing imperialist motives in particular, as it has been missing so far, and of course appropriate sanctions taken. I genuinely hope our leaders will show decisiveness, not bureaucratically shy away from confrontation. We stand with Ukraine

In my personal view, the occasional metaphors related to "dark times" diminished the power and persuasiveness of these declarations. They would have been more impactful if imperialist motives had been expressed. Using "sovereignty" would have made these statements more compelling

I looked at the declarations of these leaders irrespective of political sensitivities. Trudeau's strikes me as the most incisive + accurate one focusing on sovereignty and territorial integrity. I'm not sure why other leaders did not address this, but would be curious to know.

Whilst there seems to be a persistent failure to condemn Putin's war as an imperialist one, it could well be argued that such condemnation should be made by coalitions altogether (such as NATO, EU and G7) rather than by individual nations.

I won't look up all the declarations made by NATO members on Twitter, but this is a pretty interesting sample. Few points: this remains a social media, perhaps more has been said, and more explicitly, on national TV channels.

"Unnecessary" and "unprovoked". No. Say the words. This war is necessary to Putin's imperialist motives. Failing to expressly address this makes the "darkest hour" reference completely inept.

https://t.co/DOeceI24aa

"Unjustified attack" and "dark day", again failing to qualify this war as an imperialist one, especially deplorable since the declaration ends on a stale metaphor similar to Starmer's.

https://t.co/cEhFO1wiPN
G7 leader Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida: "Any unilateral change to the status quo by force is absolutely unacceptable". I expected absolutely nothing, yet somehow this is still disappointing.

"Unprovoked" is unnecessary especially since Trudeau then rightfully highlights the attack on Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity. Missing the one word calling it what it is: an imperialist war. Still better than all quoted above.

https://t.co/nj9L8bOZ2K

Has the merit of using 'invasion'. Although primarily catastrophic to Ukrainians being invaded, opening could be interpreted as "catastrophic for the continent since Russia leads a colonialist campaign to invade european countries". Again, say the words.

https://t.co/7EevOFZODG

"Unprovoked" and "unjustifiable". No. The justification is imperialist. This is especially disappointing from the leader of the opposition. The stale good/evil + light/darkness metaphors are deplorable when you specifically fail to name imperialism.

https://t.co/LQLt2JFiqI

"Decision to attack" and "military operations". No. Say the words. The war is explicitly an imperialist one.

https://t.co/SXHIIJH1i8

"Unprovoked" and "unjustified". No. Say the words. The justification is imperialist.

https://t.co/hYmsRYY59Q

I have only seen a handful of politicians condemning Putin's actions for what they truly are; the following steps after Crimea towards the achievement of his imperialist desire and motives. Not a mere "unprovoked attack", but a colonial campaign.

I hope the EU will finally retaliate. Bombardments have taken place 50km from EU borders. We cannot turn a blind eye to our neighbour in need of help against a multi front invasion from a dictatorship. The EU stands for nothing if it doesn't grow a spine, yesterday.
Waking up to these news has been horrifying, my heart goes to Ukrainians.

I'm sure this may sound radical. This may well sound unfair to some as well. However, alarming underrepresentation of minorities at the Bar needs radical changes to address it. Desperate times call for desperate measures.

The competitive element needs to be withdrawn for this special category of candidates at the paper sift stage. Otherwise, no matter what policy you have in place, we are still highly more likely to lose our place when a well-rounded candidate without disadvantages faces us.

These candidates, and I reiterate this is my personal view based on my personal experience and those of others I know who have faced similar significant hurdles, should be selected for interviews, provided their application satisfactorily demonstrates the right criteria.

The process should not allow that unconstrained discretion from markers who remain unconsciously unbiased. The process should not say it acknowledges disadvantages and still put these candidates in competition with others who did not, for a limited number of places for interviews

I'm going to express a completely personal view here, and a radical one: candidates with sound applications (ie meeting Chambers' criteria) who have experienced significant disadvantages (ie a severe disability, important caring resp etc) should not be put in comp with others

That very exp some sets describe as crucial. If we want to meaningfully discuss the toll the process takes on our mental health, this is it for me. Working tirelessly on apps for months just to hope they end up in the right hands. Because humans mark us. And humans are biased.

Especially relevant at this time of the year as well. Hope this wasn't discouraging to anyone, but formed one (among many) practical advice to remain realistic, seek info, and eventually achieve the best outcome for yourself and your future 🌞

I'm sure the same goes for any minority at the Bar. Progress is being made, but part of it is Chambers thinking they've already reached the goal of absolute non-discrimination, when they're very much still taking baby steps. Your career starts now, build it where it can grow.

The disabled community needs to be really tight too. We do speak together and share our horrible experiences of ableism to one another, but you need to reach out and not be afraid to ask these questions to your disabled peers. Seek these opinions above anything else.

The Bar is a small, small place. If you're disabled, don't base your opinions of Chambers on the accounts of able-bodied people. Get some minis if you can. Reach out to disabled barristers/pupils/aspiring barristers who may know.

And as someone who is currently specialising in medical ethics I am not oblivious to the need of triage protocols in times like these, but current protocols are discriminatory by holding disabled people's lives are less valuable than others'.

The toll that the need to be constantly alert and the fear of not being admitted when we need treatment has had on our mental health is immense. It is exhausting. And it is completely overlooked as all things disabled people have to put up with.

Since the pandemic has started, I have had to become even more alert than I already was to identify early signs that may mean I need to go back to Paris for treatment, to avoid triage protocols. I doubt anyone else in a smiliar situation even has a place they can trust as I do.

And this is solely because after my second relapse I was transferred to and treated at their very small and highly specialised department (Teenagers and Young Adults Leukaemia and Lymphoma Department), the most specialised in France actually, so I'm immediately sent to them.

I can't tell you how hard it is to take the eurostar alone when you're disabled with a high fever and debilitating symptoms, but this is the only place where I am not subjected to triage protocols and am always made a priority.

This is part of the reason why I insist to go back to France whenever I am really sick. I always go back to the hospital in Paris which treated me for cancer and still monitors me today. When I show up to their A&E, for whatever reason, they read my file and I am in https://t.co/NeqEfcF0ry

So my biggest 2022 resolution is to treat myself like I'd treat my bestfriend when it comes to my work and performance. To try and show myself the same level of understanding, encouragement and support. Hopefully I will be able to stick with it throughout this pup app season 🌞

I always support my friends and I'm proud of them just for getting out of bed. There is simply no justification to bring myself down for every mistake that I make like that. I would never be that hard on anyone else and it would be completely uncalled for if I ever were.
To even have been so hard on myself and always holding myself to such a high and unattainable standard is in complete opposition with how I treat others. I'm the mum friend of my group!

Now that I have realised no panel expects me to advocate as a Silk would, and that doing my best can be enough, because it has been in the past, I have more confidence in myself. That's why remembering your achievements and keep on celebrating them is so important!

But you should not forget to stop at a stop sign, and you definitely should not run anyone over 🥲. Other than these obvious mistakes (of varying unacceptable degree), it's accepted that you will make *some* small mistakes and that is, not so surprisingly, fine.

But what I failed to see then is that the panels interviewing me never expected me to be perfect in the first place. It's like taking your driving test, no one expects you to drive as if you've been doing it for 40 years!

And I found reassurance in that, I had identified the problem, hence I knew how to rectify it and do better next time. Which is pretty healthy and I was happy with that. Always thinking "I'll do better, I'll be perfect next time".

My family and friends would ask about it and I'd rave on how badly I'd fucked up (pardon my French) and how I couldn't have done worse. But as they prompted me for details, I realised I actually knew what mistakes I had made, what opportunities I had missed to make a great point.
Looking back on my journey to the Bar, I realised that I had come out of my most successful interviews (Scholarship and 1st round pup interviews) feeling like the biggest failure of all times.

I know spats and more serious arguments are all over legal Twitter right now but as the pupillage application deadline starts looking more and more dreadful for most of us, I thought I'd share one resolution I have made in the spirit of "New Year New Me".

The couple glanced at the other passengers and realised everyone was watching. They put their masks on properly to cover their nose, and sat in silence for the rest of the journey like pouting kids. And you know what? I would do it again 😌

The coach's hero (only my personal feeling) gave them a cold-eyed stare and asked "do you want to disrespect everyone in this coach any more ?" Of course all eyes were on them since the beginning of the conversation.
The person added "it's about basic respect." But our couple of antagonists decided to play dumb and dumber and only pulled their masks up to cover their mouth, sarcastically saying "happy, now ?"

And they did! Then the person said that if they were going to speak, laugh and cough, all while moving around all the time, the least they could do was to wear their masks as per the Eurostar's requirements.

But eventually someone did stand up and said "excuse me ?" to get their attention. Now we're talking about grown adults but they visibly ignored the person addressing them, until that person dropped the soft voice and sternly said "look at me when I'm talking to you."

People close to them felt visibly uncomfortable when the woman was coughing or they were laughing out loud. I thought "oh, all the other close passengers are British, because they're all uneasy but no one is going to actually say something" you know what I mean right.
They were alone around the table with 4 seats and kept moving from seat to seat happily spreading their germs all over the place in all directions.

So in the Eurostar tonight, there was a British (it's always you guys) heterosexual couple who kept their masks under their chin and they were laughing and chatting and kissing as if we were in la la land. The woman kept coughing too 💀

@AdamUpton20 I know !!! I found out that "Essex student with cancer" was actually quite famous in 2014 and no one told me I was a star ??
(I allowed it obviously, no confidentiality has been breached in this cute story 💗)

Obviously that was quite shocking news, I was told I was the first (I mean, thankfully??) so today he met me and realised, yes that was me 😌 and he knows my former haematologist really well so he will let him know I'm fine now 🥰

In his last email he wished me a speedy recovery, hoping it would be a quick one (meaning, hopefully I didn't have a refractory type, which I did) and that was it. But the doctor I saw today knew that years ago there was a student in Colchester who had got diagnosed with cancer

And when I decided to go back to France for treatment, that haematologist had to send my biopsy samples to Hospital St Louis in Paris where I was being taken care of, and we exchanged emails and I thanked him for his good care of me!

Nothing too crazy so far but here's the thing : my Hodgkin Lymphoma was diagnosed by the GP of Essex Uni, and I was then immediately transferred to Colchester's Hospital for exams, biopsies and the like. I also had a consultation with a haematologist etc

Craziest thing just happened in this small world. I had to see a doctor quite quickly at a private clinic because delays with the NHS right, and it turned out that that doctor also practises at the NHS Hospital in Colchester, doing both private and public work.

So if that's you reading, keep your head up, better days will come, especially once you get the support that you need. But for that to happen you need to reach out first, to your friends, family, and specialists. Make sure to build yourself the best support system you can ❤

I have made it clear that my health issues will never stop me, that I want to be open about them because I want people dealing with similar problems, feeling low, to know they can be happy, fulfilled, successful. I want to share the joy and pride of overcoming these hurdles !

But daily life is still difficult, when you don't sleep 2 to 3 nights in a row every week, it's soul-draining. Sure, I somehow manage my academic and work life well, but being so exhausted is unhealthy. I will receive adequate support now so all is good and the future's bright 🌞

Thankfully I was treated with corticosteroids for several years due to my bone marrow transplants side effects (how did I manage to start this sentence with "thankfully" ??) so that helped me tremendously. I was finally able to develop coping mechanisms that I have stuck to.

There can be many other reasons for it to go undetected as well. For example, I always did really well at school without any effort. Everybody called me lazy, said I was relying too much on my potential instead of putting in the work. I couldn't put in the work, but I wanted to.

I've had the news for a little while but I wanted to take the time to process it before being open about it. Especially because it is severely under-diagnosed in women, so whoever may be reading this and think they might have it, go see a specialist 🙏

It took 27 years before a doctor looked at my extreme insomnia and how chronically sleep deprived I've been my entire life, in addition to some other issues, and said "you have ADHD", do you hear this?TWENTY SEVEN YEARS.

Many barristers I met during my minis went out of their way to help me realize my potential ('your accent is perfect don't be apologetic', 'your analysis is strong and concise') and I can thank them for having helped me build confidence in myself that I belong at the Bar.

Having the opportunity to ask questions about the Bar I never had the chance to ask anyone else at that stage was also really helpful to me in order to narrow down which practice areas were a good fit for me

Otherwise all but one of my minis have been extremely valuable to me and loads of fun. I enjoyed being given papers to read and analyze, being questioned on my understanding of the facts and issues, being explained the things I'd missed in a very encouraging way

Any suggestion to improve the difficult situation that aspiring barristers are facing today needs to take into account that the Bar Course is the first opportunity for many people to work towards their goal to join the Bar in tangible ways.

I still don't have a pupillage offer, but I made it to the final rounds, my first time applying, in the middle of a pandemic. You cannot say I have no chance of succeeding, though it will undoubtedly be a difficult journey.
It was finally during the BPTC that I had access to support and assistance to understand the process of pupillage applications and how to work my way towards joining the Bar.

Implement the requirement to hold a pupillage offer to study the Bar Course, and I, a disabled BPTC graduate with an Inn's scholarship, would have NEVER made it. It was only during the BPTC that I finally had access to lots of opportunities to hone my skills and enhance my CV.

As many of you know, I had to study my LLB from France, remotely, because I was in and out of hospital, undergoing chemo and bone marrow transplant etc. Needless to say, there was no opportunity for me to do mooting/debating/a good amount of pro bono work/loads of minis.
You think you can keep your cool, you think you can do well under pressure, and then suddenly you play Dead by Daylight and it all goes out the window.

@NischayMall Thank you Nischay, I've read a bit about compulsory licensing as I'm trying to understand what is going on despite my lack of knowledge of IP law, which is definitely a niche and complex area. I hope this situation is resolved asap, this is purely awful.

Disclaimer : I am no expert in IP law and do not suggest in any way that I am. I am merely telling the story of a doctor who understood what 'necessity' means and how that outweighs any other factor when lives are lost or at significant risk everywhere around the world.

The world has been going through trying and uncertain times, people are dying based on where they were born, every necessary effort must be made to ensure that everyone is given the means to survive this dreadful pandemic. This is not a time for profits, but a time for solidarity
If he had decided to receive a single cent per hand sanitizer sold, he would have earned 1,6 billion euros a year. But he said: "hand hygiene is too necessary to be patented."
We are lucky to have been born in rich countries and that's it. Nothing more but sheer dumb luck. Mr Pittet understood that very well and made the moral decision to give his formula to WHO.
Patents are obstructing affordable covid vaccines and create delays in getting vaccine supplies which results in thousands and thousands of unnecessary deaths around the world.

Many, many more would have died from covid as well. We would ALL have been affected even more, to an unimaginable degree, by this pandemic. If you think the situation in our western countries is bad, think about what it would have been without hand sanitizer.

There is no justification to withhold the covid vaccines' formulas and materials from these countries.

If Mr Pittet had done such a thing, 8 million lives a year for the past 25 years would not have been saved.

The covid vaccines, their formulas, the materials they require, are today an absolute necessity. It is ethically wrong to proceed like this and keep it from countries who need it most.

We're listening to the reports on the situation in India, we're seeing the shocking images.

What did he do with his formula? He gave it to WHO in the early 2000's. Patent-free. He wanted to prevent pharmaceutical companies from rendering it inaccessible to countries who needed it most, for profits. He wanted to make sure everyone, around the world, could access it.

However, Mr Pittet did come up with a working formula that he developed to reduce nosocomial infections. A fantastic and life-changing product that has impacted our lives, worldwide, far beyond what we know or could imagine, even before the pandemic.

Now, Mr Pittet did not invent hand sanitizer per se. Its invention is actually quite unclear, including references to a nurse in California, Guadalupe Hernandez, as the original inventor in 1960, but without any evidence she's actually ever existed.

We owe hand sanitizer as we know it today to Didier Pittet, a Swiss doctor nicknamed 'Mr clean hands'. You know how useful it's been with covid, but even before the pandemic, it's been estimated that Mr Pittet saved 8 millions lives per year with his formula for hand sanitizer.

The situation in India and the western countries' refusal to share formulas and materials for everyone to manufacture the vaccines because of IP rights such as patents, makes me think a lot about where the world would be now without hand sanitizer. Hear me out.

In light of the development of social media and the increased violence on here, we would all benefit from taking cyberbullying into consideration before diving into arguments in which we're not even involved, asking ourselves what damage our statements can potentially lead to.

I have searched for tweets mentioning B, some are extremely, EXTREMELY violent, especially in light of the alleged tort caused. I share this as a reminder : you may feel compelled to tweet about something, you may feel it is right to do so, but the consequences can be dramatic.
C has 360 000 followers. The tweet was deleted after at least half an hour, following a plethora of comments outlining how this was bound to lead to cyberbullying.

A famous French lawyer (C), similar to SB here, then took it upon him to tweet about this, publicly identifying B with her Twitter name containing her last name, telling her that she was in breach of her code of Conduct.
A has 5 600 followers. B has 200. You can imagine how this is going, but it can be argued that A is entitled to bring this publicly.

B alleges that she didn't know whose notes these ones were, and apologizes. A does not delete the tweets. Many people interfere, some discuss whether B could be sued for stealing intellectual property.

How many notes in the entire file were actually A's is disputed, but it seems A's notes formed 1/3 of the file. A is warned by someone else that this is happening and decides to tweet about it, publicly sharing B's Twitter name, which contains B's last name.

Last year, one French Bar student (A) publicly shared her revision notes, for the french Bar school entrance exam, for free. A learned today that someone (B) was currently sharing them in exchange for retweets, pretending the notes were hers.

@TajwarShelim This! I absolutely love the Serenity Prayer in a non religious way, when I find things too frustrating at times, I often remind myself that I need 'the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, courage to change the things I can, and wisdom to know the difference'.

I really hope that things soon take a brighter turn for everyone who's feeling rock-bottom at the moment, and I hope everyone manages to remind themselves that their ability to succeed in any given field or career, at any point of time, cannot ever determine their personal value.

That sense of detachment, being able to take that step back, is really helpful to me, while I see my friends and other aspiring barristers on here feeling very discouraged and disheartened. Which is totally legitimate! But I wish I could share that little piece of inner serenity
Including pupillage applications, as much as I am determined to get one, as much as I want to be a barrister, no one is going to die if things do not happen immediately the way I wish they would.

One thing I'm glad I learned from being in a literal life or death situation (which went on for several years) is that if something is not health-related, it shouldn't get to me. It can be improved, avoided, or worked around. That's what I apply to everything I do.

I may be cynical, but I do believe that the restrictions on our freedom to merely exist within public spaces, on our own, will not change just because we all mourn yet another victim. We, all women, need to force that change.

The similar murder of Victoirine Dartois in France in 2019 sparked that conversation here too. We all said 'it could have been any of us, this is what happens to us everyday'. And everyone was outraged. Yet, no substantial change happened, no policy measures were taken.

I am legitimately furious at everything women have to endure, at the untenable safety measures that we have to take permanently. And I am sadly certain that what happened to Sarah Everard will not spark a significant change to this.

The numbers of times that I have been harassed in the streets, subjected to disgusting sexual comments, in London, is also unbelievable. I always pretend that I don't speak English to take them aback a bit and escape the situation, but I am sick and tired of it.

At 18 yo, taking the first metro (tube equivalent) in the morning in France to go home after a night out, alone, a man sat in front of me. The train was empty. He started masturbating ostensibly while looking at me. That is what happens to women who defy our implicit curfew.

The only times at which I feel safe, is when my male partner is by my side. As a proud feminist, who wants nothing more than to reclaim my right to enjoy public places, I hate that I depend on the person I love to feel safe outside. That I am not enough, without him, to be safe.

I am insomniac, I love night-time, I love walking outside in that peaceful atmosphere. Except that because I am woman, it never can be peaceful. The threat is constant, the bad encounters are not rare. I just don't belong in public places at my preferred hours. I am a woman.

My mum would repeteadly tell me to scream and kick any man harassing me outside if they wouldn't leave me alone. She started when I was 8 yo so I'd learn quickly to never trust a man outside when I was alone. She taught me I needed to constantly be alert, for the rest of my life.

When I was 17, at my French high school, as I was walking towards the bus station to go have lunch at home, a 30 year old man driving his car stopped near me and asked me if I'd like a ride. I politely refused, he wouldn't take no for an answer until I started screaming.

One of the first times I took the tube to Chancery Lane, after having moved to London in 2019, I witnessed a man upskirting a woman in front of me. I was furious, called him out publicly, and no one backed me up. No one stood up for her or for me.

I always, always look down to follow the shadow of any man behind me in the street, to see if they are following me, or speeding up to catch up. I'm tired of never feeling safe outside. The first times I've been followed and harassed took place when I was a young teenager.

As usual, sorry for the typos, it's 1am and I should be asleep already, but I felt it was important to have this conversation. How do we encourage disabled aspiring barristers to apply? And what doesn't work? This thread is merely the beginning of an answer and my own views only.

Personally, I feel uncomfortable having to include this sensitive information in a covering email. You do not yet know me, but I have to tell you what's gone wrong first. It feels close to humiliating, because there are many other, better things that I'd prefer to open with.

My application will then has to 'make up' for it. To show that I am still apt, in spite of these facts.

On the other hand, with a mitigation circs box on the form, I can expand on how my achievements have to be seen in this wider context, and are even more impressive then.

And these things can be entirely unconscious. The fact is this is not how I want someone to meet me. If we were meeting face to face in a personal context, I would not be introducing myself by starting with this information.

You may not think of yourself as an ableist person, thankfully, but ableism is a systemic oppression which lives inside all of us to a certain degree. Reading about my health issues first, sets a negative tone for the actual application.

The covering email is the first thing you're going to read about us. For me, that means you'll read about how I had cancer 4x and now experience a range of disabilities such as chronic fatigue and osteonecrosis which impacts my mobility to a certain degree even if not visible.

If your non-Gateway pupillage application form does not contain a box for mitigation circumstances, but you instead encourage disabled applicants to speak about those in their covering email, I feel strongly that this is not the way to go about it.

@mequissa I'm so tired I read your tweet the wrong way the 1st time 😂 I generally add information about my disabilities in this box if no other space is dedicated to it, or I may specify that I'm unavailable on certain dates due to medical appointments if no other space for that either!

Requiring documents and proofs that can only be obtained from local authorities/administrations that are notoriously outrageously inaccessible for all the reasons listed above, without offering any support, is not the way to go about it.

I don't even want to criticize Brexit because it's done and I'm not a UK citizen anyway, it's not my place. But any process that relates to it and has such a life-changing impact must be clear, easy to find and understand, and accessible to all disabled people.

I cannot imagine what this process must be like to anyone in a less fortunate position, people struggling with local authorities/other administrations due to language barrier/illiteracy/difficulties to access the correct information/lack of resources/inaccessible services...

I'm not disabled in a way that renders the process inaccessible to me, I am literate, I have the resources including the financial means to obtain all the evidence I need and prove the duration of our relationship.

And at least I've got a legal background, a law degree, the Bar Course, several legal work experiences etc, I can read and understand legislation, I can make solid applications that are strongly evidenced. I know the sort of docs I need and how to get them.
The anxiety that my partner won't be granted pre-settled status to move to the UK with me in August, is just through the roof.

Probably not the most fancy hobby you'd expect from a future barrister, and thankfully not my only hobby either, but I do think we could quite interestingly discuss how you can/must develop and use some necessary skills for this career by playing certain video games.

And finally, I really enjoy open world games because I love a good narrative combined with all the possibilities of exploration which enable you to really build your own adventure, based on your personality. Video games are hugely underestimated.

For example, I'd give anything to play Among Us with fellow BPTC students/grads, the level and nature of debating would be so interesting. I also love horror games because you need to stay calm and make rational decisions at the most urgent and difficult times.

I really like playing video games and would so love that it wasn't such a misogynistic community. I think it's a great way to keep in touch and hang out with friends in these times but so many games also require you to think strategically and actually advocate persuasively.

Working hard, on top of everything an aspiring barrister has to be juggling with, so that disabled students and all other students that were discriminated against (such as international students and students wearing the hijab) aren't overlooked and that it never happens again.

The months-long discrimination against us never sparked a similar outrage as the fact that some students had to pee in a cup. I will always be furious about this and it's the reason why I will keep on working closely with SABER admins.

We have been discriminated against in times where the pandemic was hitting our communities the hardest. Now that was a harrowing experience. We wrote letters, we campaigned. And we were blatantly ignored.

I will quite never get past the fact that what attracted attention was that some students had to relieve themselves into glasses/cups/buckets while on camera during exams. That was horrendous. But disabled and international students had been calling for help for months in vain.

In 2020, future barristers were discriminated against by their regulatory body because of their disability. This was done to lawyers. The legal framework didn't prevent it, and it was completely overlooked. Society hasn't made the progress it likes to congratulate itself for. https://t.co/y5oYrltEFk

Many of my colleagues, who are vulnerable, will have to put their health at risk to sit in December and while I understand that not everyone has a choice, I sincerely hope that those who materially can prioritize their health, will do it. No qualification is worth such a risk.

I've got my check up appointment with my surgeon on the day that the results of Ethics are released and again, whatever mark I get, I have absolutely no regret for prioritizing my health and not sitting in October. This surgery was more important. Your health always comes first.

The Bar will never adequately represents people as long as this is permitted, as long as any disruption such as the coronavirus is used to restrict access to the profession. The BSB ought to have done better and it will be of critical importance to hold them accountable.

The 2020 BPTC exams have more than even before served the purpose of ensuring that only wealthy English/Welsh students with no disabilities, no caring responsibilities, no pressing need to earn income, no vulnerability to the virus, will access the Bar. This is a massive issue.

Those who failed are mentally on edge. Financially on edge. Some may have been able to sit again in October, but not all. Not international students. Those who won't be materially able to resit are students from underrepresented background, those we desperately NEED at the Bar.

Those who passed do not feel like they have achieved something or that their hard work paid off, there is no joy nor pride. They're just exhausted and relieved they won't have to go through that emotionally and financially soul-draining process.

A number of students are going to sleep tonight not having received their results as planned while everybody else did and I just keep thinking if it had been me I would have gone insane. Wellbeing is a meaningless mere marketing tool being waved around. Shameful @barstandards

When I see an amazing work experience being advertised on Twitter, and quite rightly many people retweeting it, highlighting how great it is and what difference it will make to someone's CV, it's quite frustrating. Because it's almost never accessible to me. I can't even apply.

Less than 6% of barristers are disabled. This number is not only not going to improve, due to the pandemic it will decrease significantly. Active steps must be taken to ensure disabled aspiring barristers are treated fairly and that these circumstances will be taken into account.

I say rivals because while I love and support all my colleagues, we can not forget getting pupillage is a fierce competition. There is no level playing field and yet, we will be judged in the same way.

The range of work experiences that were accessible to disabled aspiring barristers was low pre-covid, but at a time where most if not all of us have to shield, there is almost nothing left at all. This is worryingly increasing the gap between us and our able-bodied rivals.

So, is it a good measure? Yes. Is it pressing? No. Will it make a difference to the oppression of French women? No. Is it made in good faith at least? No. Are there other things they'd be doing if they cared about women? Hell yes. But, do they care? No.

Instead, this measure is an attack on the Muslim community, and part of the Government's proclaimed fight on separatism. Weirdly enough, this battle focuses solely on the Muslim community, other separatisms that are undeniably present in France are not targeted the slightest.

It's critical to understand what this measure is. In no way does this meaningfully help women and protect them. It would, if it were part of a bigger picture, with other measures that would primarily deal with the most pressing issues women face.

There is no current evidence that this is a wide issue, but this is what they chose to spend resources on. Not on the widely reported police's refusals to hear victims of rape. Not on the rising number of victims of domestic violence, who the police also wilfully ignore. https://t.co/PwmOQdH5im

I feel old, I am starting to have a lot of life stories!
I guess sometimes, freshers week is not all terrible (although I have much more dreadful stories with awful people from the little time I spent at the Uni of Surrey 😫)!

I guess in terrible times, some things truly invaluable come out. This friendship definitely is one. Now don't ever tell her I said this if you happen to know who I'm talking about, but she's one of the most amazing people I met and I cherish her friendship.

She'd yell at me for the all-nighters spent on the white book and would make me dinner when I was too tired to, we'd watch our favorite show every Wednesday with takeaway and no amount of BPTC homework would have stopped me!

But that one friend and I remained particularly close. She visited me in France multiple times, came with me to chemo, came back again for my birthday. She's the best. And this year when I was back in London, she was my flatmate once again 💗

Now you know me!! I quickly pulled myself together and told my family the bad news so we could organize my return to France. My friends supported me, they came with me for the biopsy at the hospital in Colchester, made a goodbye party for me and gave me gifts I still have.

I was alone in England at first, but with everyone there I actually had many people around me that really cared for me. When I received the call that gave me the news, I cried at the shock for a solid 10 minutes, and one friend in particular comforted me.

I hardly speak about it but I was diagnosed with cancer in March 2014, in my first year of LLB at Uni of Essex. I was very close to everyone in my flat, almost everyone in my building actually, we'd often speak of ourselves as a family, it was exactly like that.

But really, it shouldn't be harder than how it's been today for me. And indeed, it can be that simple. Don't be fooled by speeches claiming that there was no other way and that the UK gov has done its best, they haven't.

Now I know that in Paris, results at the moment take a long time to be obtained due to mass demands and insufficient preparation by our government, I'm not saying France is doing it perfectly, you all know how (highly) critical I am of those governing us here.

I was given a leaflet on how to access my results and one on how to behave until I got my results + what to do afterwards depending on whether I'm positive or negative. I said 'au revoir et bon courage !' and went home. All in all, I spent less than 45min outside, drive included.

There were 2 seats that were disinfected in between each patients and doctors would change their gloves and apron as well. Every time. I sat there when I was called, slightly pulled my mask down, got tested, and was good to go. Results in 24-36h max, online.
I waited a few minutes to get booked in and give the nurse my administrative details, after which I was directed to another tent where I waited maybe 15 minutes before my turn.

I booked the test at a test center in one of the hospitals in the city I am currently in (in Britanny). We drove there, followed the arrows to the car park reserved for the tests, were told where to park and where to go then.

I booked an appointment for today at a suitable time for me (2pm). Going today is not too early before the surgery so the test will still be relevant, but also sufficiently early before the surgery so as to have the results for sure.

I'm aware of the situation in England so let me tell you about my covid test in France. I needed one prior to undertaking a surgery for which I will be hospitalized starting from Monday. A week ago, I went online on the service widely used by healthcare practitioners (doctolib).

Nowhere else would have I gotten exactly all that I needed, but at Gray's, I did. I think that's a relevant consideration I too rarely hear mentioned. Think of your own individual financial needs when making the decision of where to apply. That'd be my only advice.

+ taxis for when I'm unable to use public transports. I knew that anything less than a huge sum covering all of this would not realistically be enough for me to study the BPTC. It was more than tuition fees, I had particular financial needs.

Getting back to this, I chose Gray's because I knew there'd be fewer scholarships offered (smallest Inn) and as a result, I'd get more money. As a disabled student I needed a lot, to fully cover the BPTC fees, but also to help me pay for accessible housing in London

Oh wow, that's a lot of notifications. I try to use my birthdays every year to share my story and get people to know more about bone marrow transplants so I'm very happy to see so many people engaging with this and learning about this procedure, thank you 💗
📴 for the day

He also expected me to be remarkable at what I do and he was insanely proud of my first class degree and Inn scholarship. I hope to continue to make him proud and will always be thankful for having had this man in my life who cherished me so much. Will always miss you. https://t.co/TdOa0XfJag

That I would live many more years was his only wish and there is no better day than the one I'm getting older to pay tribute to him. He taught me about the importance of kindness and compassion, he helped me be a good person, leading by example.
4) Today I am also saying goodbye to my grandfather at his funeral. To this man I owe the confidence that I can achieve anything, and from reading this thread, you know that I indeed can.

And please share the knowledge around you. I wouldn't be here without this procedure, I cherish my new bone marrow. Be the person that makes this gift to someone else if you can, and encourage others to do it too. You can find all the information here : https://t.co/3njANNKMld

There is only one in a million chances that someone who is not a blood relative will be a match. 80% of the donations are not surgeries anymore but akin to blood donation instead. If you'd like to make me a birthday present, please read about becoming a donor, it's essential.

Now here comes the crux of this thread, I'd like to emphasize the only reason I am cancer-free is thanks to the bone marrow transplant I have received. There is a lot to say about bone marrow transplants.

That means : with love, fun, friends and family, everything I love I have to do. That includes training as a barrister because I genuinely love it. But it also includes playing video games, reading all night long like a kid defying curfew, singing out loud in the car, etc...

Better, my liver recovered. Better again, my immune system got me into remission on its own. I have been on remission ever since. Birthdays remind me of that, every year I get is a bonus, and I need to live my life the best way I can to enjoy it. Nothing else matters.

I just didn't have long, I wasn't responding to the medicine. 
But I kept living, I moved to Britanny to be with my partner, I kept studying law, I took driving lessons, I attended my sister's wedding. I just kept living. And I miraculously started to respond to the medicine.

3) Notwithstanding points 1 & 2, I like birthdays because I'm aware I shouldn't be getting them at all. 3 years ago, I had severe hepatic failure due to the latest treatment I'd received for my 4th occurrence of cancer. I was dying, I was told so, my parents were told so.

Be it personally or professionally, there is so much that I need to do. I always feel like I am running out of time. If I were a Musical character I'd be Hamilton. Birthdays are a reminder of that deadline and I feel the irrepressible need to do more and more. It's never enough.

2) Due to the treatments I have received, I am very likely to die at a not-that-old age. I won't die tomorrow, but I most likely won't reach retirement either. That is insufferable to me. I am as ambitious as it gets.

1) Birthdays cause me mixed feelings. I can't stop feeling like I have lost 5 years of my life (19-24) fighting cancer. Birthdays are a reminder that I have been the victim of what feels like an irreparable injustice, and I don't seem to be wise enough to find peace about it.

International students had to travel far and pay to sit their exams at a test center. Students sitting remotely had to relieve themselves on camera while staring at the webcam. They experienced major disruption due to tech failures and waiting times of sometimes 3 hours.

This year, disabled and international students spent weeks trying to book their exams, losing revision time, put under unbearable stress. Disabled students sat without their RAs, sometimes at test centers 3 hours of commute away from their home, at 8am.

SABER was born out of horrible circumstances but we made something great out of this nightmare. I am very thankful for these people who have become friends, they deserve all the applause they can get for their hard work and kindness. ❤️ @blwstndrdsbrd

With SABER I have realized that I am quite good at strategizing and advocating, far better than I give myself credit for. I have developed many skills. I have gained a lot of confidence. I have received very helpful advice for my future career. It's an amazing organization.

The side of SABER you don't see is people who:
_ take over your workload if you need it, no questions asked
_ give a LOT of advice on pupillage
_ discuss your concerns
_ put you in contact with other people to talk to
_ are just overall the most supportive people I have ever met
(In this house, we support each other and share tips because we do not fear the competition, we embrace it 🔥 good luck everyone!)

Also, for colleagues interested at a career at the Criminal Bar, Interpol is based in Lyon and regularly take on interns in many fields including law. They also recruit for more permanent positions from time to time.

And so, I understand the good intentions in saying that these results won't determine these kids' future, because we did get away with it. But it does determine their future, let's not pretend otherwise. When you come from a disadvantaged background, that's all you've got.

I cannot imagine how it must feel to get unremarkable, if not bad, results through no fault of yours, after actually putting all the work in. I have been incredibly hard working in my further studies, and would have been devastated to be deprived of the marks I deserved.

The thing is that my unremarkable results (over which I cried, because I regretted not putting in any work back then and not achieving a stellar overall mark which I knew I could have gotten, and later did in my studies) were entirely down to me, being lazy and not interested.

I managed to get into a very selective course thanks to my personal statement and 2 great letters of recommendation. I owe these letters to my privileged background, I was in a good school, not a super fancy one, but a good one still.

I have a French baccalaureate, equivalent of A Levels, and let me tell you I was one lazy pupil and only got 13,7/20 overall, which is absolutely unremarkable and wouldn't get you anywhere selective. I have been very lucky that it did not really impact my further studies.

If you want to hear (well, read) a cute story, I'm very reluctant to cut my hair (and it's starting to get long-long and annoying) because its length shows how long my partner and I have been together, 4 years 🥺

Thank you for reading, those who know me know I am strong, witty, outspoken, and absolutely hate being vulnerable more than anything in the world. This thread has been written and re written a dozen times. But I finally decided that it was too important to be left unsaid.

And I want the person responsible for the vivid flashbacks I now get multiple times a day, to apologize and resign. I never want anyone else in the future to be harmed like I and many others have been.
And for this, for this direct attack on my health and the health of so many of my colleagues, I want reparation. I want every demand made by SABER, of which I am a proud member, to be met.

I get up 8 or 10 times at night to check that everything is alright because I can just feel that something is wrong. There's nothing wrong of course. That never happened prior to my regulator subjecting me to such an upsetting and discriminatory treatment.

I had been suspecting PTSD for about a year now, because I would have flashbacks and symptoms every now and then, from time to time. I was going to seek treatment once I had the time to, after the BPTC. I didn't need to have my situation aggravated like this.

I have become incredibly irritable, my heart is always racing at at least 120bpm, I feel physically sick for no reason several times a day, I have vivid nightmares when I do sleep. I didn't even tell my partner or friends about this.
The way the BSB has treated my cohort is appalling and has really tangibly damaged our health. For me, this is how it manifested. This is the impact it has had on my mental health:

feeling that what was done to me was truly unfair and I couldn't escape it, I felt cursed. The feeling was too familiar, and even though we are 'only' talking exams here (the most important ones in our lives still), not cancer, it really triggered something in me.

However, it has only been diagnosed now because the symptoms really escalated since early June. They became more and more unbearable, as, regarding the exams, I had to be put in an incredibly stressful time of uncertainty, with absolutely no control over the situation, and -

Flashbacks of the incredibly painful moments I've gone through became far more frequent and intense. There is a stigma that comes with mental health issues and so I know this would be easier left unsaid. But I have PTSD as a result of the agressive treatments I have received.

A month ago, I was diagnosed with PTSD. I've always been insomniac, but I had reached a point where I couldn't sleep at all, for days and days, throwing up out of exhaustion all day long. I was constantly on alert. Ready for something to happen, always.
I have had to go through so much, really you could never even get close to imagine it, you ought to be trying really hard to finally get to me. And the BSB did, eventually, get to me.

In my group of friends, I'm the strong one. The one who always speaks up. Hell, those who know me know I'll stand up to anyone and I really do not fear anything. I don't get aggrieved by things over which others usually do.

cost me which should have gone to revising, the uncertainty, then having to opt for a test center within 24 hours without knowing how my adjustments would be met there (all of them weren't), the booking chaos... Eventually, it has impacted me, even if I wish that it hadn't.

As I am disabled, the organisation of these exams has been incredibly appalling and stressful. Being initially told I could not have my reasonable adjustments at all, having to work with my colleagues on fighting for getting our reasonable adjustments, the time and energy it -

It is no secret that I have fought cancer 4 times, and won against all odds, nor is it a secret that I am disabled as a result. I try to be open about this because I am working on being proud of the person I have become, instead of dwelling on the past and the person I used to be

Well it's really late and I can't sleep, so, this is something quite personal, and I have been carefully thinking about whether to share this, but I think it's important to really highlight how the way the BSB has treated us has been detrimental to our mental health.

The news of her death today incredibly saddens me. France has lost a fierce and beautiful soul. I trust that the feminist movement will not forget our mothers and grandmothers before us, and will harness all of their energy and knowledge, to win the fights they lived to fight.

She supported the abolition of the death penalty. In 1981 she was elected to the French National Assembly. She supported the decriminalization of homosexuality. But she felt that her political power was smothered by the 'misogynistic stronghold', which she fearlessly denounced.

She signed the Manifesto of the 343 in 1971, a necessary act of civil disobedience to fight for women's rights and the right to dispose of their bodies as they wanted to, notably by getting an abortion. French women, we owe them everything. And we never forget it.

With Simone de Beauvoir, she was one of the most important feminist figures advocating for women's rights and especially, the right to get an abortion. She represented a 17 year old who had illegally aborted after she had been raped, in the famous Bobigny trial in 1972. She won.

She notably acted for Djamila Boupacha in 1960, who had been tortured.
She was a major feminist activist, she campaigned for rape to be recognized as a crime instead of a lesser offence.

Gisèle Halimi, born in 1927 in Tunisia, supported Tunisia and Algeria's Independence, which were French colonies, by denouncing the torture used by the French military in Algeria. She represented members of the Algerian National Liberation Front in Court.

When I was young(er), I used to think 'Gisèle Halimi is a hero, I want to be like her when I grow up'.
Now I'm a proud radical feminist, a few exams away from becoming a lawyer.
Gisèle Halimi passed away today. She can rest in peace; the next generation will carry on her legacy.

3) If the BSB could not then assess that these discriminations would arise, their Equality Impact Analysis process is flawed and ineffective. It must be reviewed and improved. I would suggest looking at their recruitment process for the individuals in charge of these analyses.

In the meantime on planet Earth, the BSB has been so focused on upholding this superficial and wrong appearance of rigour that they completely failed at implementing a truly rigourous process, ensuring that students would be marked on their knowledge and skills alone.

The BSB's incorrect definition of 'rigour' implies that students somehow have to suffer through the BPTC in order to be deserving of the qualification, and that many have to fail for the qualification to be acknowledged as prestigious and a clear sign of excellence.

As if asking disabled students to waive their RAs was the definition of rigour. As if forcing critically vulnerable students to travel to test centers was the definition of rigour. As if refusing students the right to go to the loo was the definition of rigour.

We asked for open book exams (we shouldn't even have had to) early on (first time back in March) and were always told the exams would not be rigorous at all this way. As if asking Malaysian students to travel to another country in times of pandemic was the definition of rigour.

A rigorous examination is one that ensures every student sits it with the same fair chance of success, based solely on their hard work, and irrespectively of their background. It's nothing like what we've seen with the BSB so far. It had to have been open book.

If we all do our part when we can, we make sure that no one ever feels safe when shamelessly abusing others in public places. End of thread!

Always use your voice and take the impunity away from them. I have found myself more than once the subject of harassment from men in public and I wish someone would have spoken up as I did this morning.

I know it's easy to look away, but if you're in the position where you do not risk anything, why would you look away to begin with? If it's because it makes you uncomfortable, the person being abused feels much more uncomfortable than you will.

I will not let anyone make racist comments, I can easily stop it because I'm white and I know people won't assume I was the harasser. I will not let anyone harass an employee, because I am also a customer and can easily stop it, I know I do not risk anything.

They all know it, so they all have to put up with the abuse instead.
That's why I consider it a moral duty that we each have, to step in and speak up when we share the specific feature of the abuser which gives them power in that specific instance.

There are deep social implications which prevent the person abused or anyone around sharing their features from speaking up. Customers could be fired. Black people could be blamed, even though they're the ones being harassed. Women fear physical violence from men in public.

About people being abusive in public, they always do it because they're in a situation of power (customer/employee, white person/black person, man/woman) which causes them to feel a strong sense of impunity. And they're right, too rarely does anyone speak up.
I AM HAVING GOOD FOOD 🙏

*continues, please ignore all the typos in this thread as I was typing as fast as I could before losing signal on the Eurostar 😔

The customer shrugged and went to sit in the train. She then was told by another person who sat in her coach that racist lady had been prevented from taking the train and that the police had been called. And you know what? I'd do it all over again.

Then racist lady loses it and as the customer takes the lift and goes to the platform, she screams insanities and promises to finish her off, a whole lot of 'if I see you up there I WILL FUCKING END YOU YOU HEAR ME END YOU OKAY' (still in French) (still in front of her toddler)

On their way to the lift, they walk behind racist lady. Racist lady looks at the customer aggressively and makes a derogatory noise. The customer has had enough and replies with something to the effect that she's a bloody disgrace (still in French).

The employee discreetly turned to the customer and thanked her. Then it turned out that the customer who had raised her voice was disabled even though it wasn't visible, because the employee took her and her only to a lift.

Racist lady turns to her starts going off on her 'I didn't speak to you, shut the fuck up' etc. The girl firmly repeats 'Enough' (all in French). Another woman who appears to be a friend of racist lady taps on her shoulder and tells her to let it go. She reluctantly stops.
The employee simply continue to politely ask her to make way. The second customer has enough of this abuse and stands up yelling 'OH. I SAID ENOUGH.' (in French)

Then she goes on yelling insanities. Another customer, sitting behind the employee, raises her tone at the same time to order racist agressive Lady to stop abusing this employee. Mean lady ignores the other customer and keeps on screaming at the employee who says nothing.

The employee asked again a minute later and the woman went off on her, incredibly agressively, with a clear racist undertone (in front of her child!) still in French. She yelled stuff like 'YOU NEED TO LEARN FUCKING FRENCH YOU FUCKING IDIOT' (in French) (remember we're in London)

Since I had not been contacted by @CityLawSchool as I should have been, I emailed the Disability Support on Monday to agree an appointment to discuss my needs and what the heck is going on ASAP. I got an appointment on Friday. Deadline for a test center expires tomorrow.

I then received an email from @CityLawSchool at almost 11am this morning telling me I needed to let them know if I wanted to take my exams at a test center, before tomorrow 3pm. No mention of how my specific RA would be met at a test center.

Adding to my last RT, while the @barstandards stated in their guide released on Monday that students with reasonable adjustments had been contacted by their providers to assess their needs, I never was contacted by @CityLawSchool

This outbreak wouldn't be as remotely as stressful as it is if our countries had been properly prepared, and if we all knew that everyone, despite their country of origin, their income and medical conditions, was going to be materially supported and assisted. End of thread

While I don't wish for people to fall into paranoia over this virus, it's important to realize that any medical condition makes you ultra vulnerable and you might not survive a contamination. We must act collectively to prevent that, and we must protect those who can't afford it

My immune system is 4 years old, I'm more fragile than children, and I'm lucky that my family helped me getting prepared by buying me expensive masks and sanitizer. Being lucky in that way is far from being the norm. Action is urgent
The same will go as climate crisis worsen, we have a prime example right here right now of who will suffer the most. People in power with loads of money can afford not to care, we cannot

What we see, and what we already knew, is that with any sort of public health crisis, the most precarious ones will be the most impacted because they cannot afford essentials to protect themselves and that is appalling

Following the virus outbreak in Italy, the price of essentials in this public health crisis, such as sanitizer and masks, were raised insanely high. Which was to be expected. Now what's the excuse of France and the UK for failing to even think of that and act upon it ?

It's so very frustrating to work this hard, all the time, for so long, only to have it wasted in seconds due to my body refusing to sleep and my school forgetting that I had special arrangements. I can't do anything about it now but, well, I'm disappointed

It was a safe one for me. And although I know I didn't do so badly that I failed, I'm sure I've missed the higher marks I would have secured. I spent time trying to order my thoughts despite the dizziness, trying to remember my words, trying to articulate well despite the nausea.

I've worked insanely hard on my advocacy skills, especially examination in chief, I was more than prepared, and I relied on this module as one of those which would definitely raise the Bar (pun intended) of my overall results.
I couldn't sit before the assessment started to calm it down, and you all know you cannot sit during an examination in chief either. It impacted my performance so much, I am incredibly frustrated.

Which means the chronic fatigue is worsened too, and I get extremely nauseous in the morning, and especially after any physical effort. After that flight of stairs, that I took as slowly as I could to minimize its impact, left me dizzy, intensely nauseous, and in pain.

It was one of these questions where you both know you can't say no. So I said yes, of course. But truth is my insomnia has been firing up the past few days, as you probably can tell. I have only slept one hour in the past 72 hours. There's nothing I can do for that

But somehow I found out this morning that I had been allocated to a room on the second floor, to which the lift doesn't go. The inviligator, embarrassed, especially since I came with one crutch today, asked me if I could do it

I arrived early to meet with the inviligator and find out to which room I had been allocated. I had received an email confirming that my appointment for this assessment had taken into account my special arrangements.
